You might want to try to evolve a player without coevolution first  to make=
 sure that everything else is working.  In my HyperNEAT library, I have a t=
ic tac toe experiment where the evaluation plays against an "everything" pl=
ayer.  Basically, whenever it is the everything player's turn, that player =
creates a new game for every possible action.  In other words, if the every=
thing player moves first, he creates nine copies of the game state, one for=
 each first move, and the hyperneat player plays all nine of these games (w=
hich then expand into more games, etc.)  This is tractable because tic tac =
toe is such a small search space.  I like this approach because it is easy =
to know when you have achieved a perfect player, since every possible game =
state that could be reached given the individual's current policy is presen=
ted.

ry simple. The problem is that even the

ll sucks, and I was kind of implicitly 
> promising a near-optimal player n=
ext. It's funny how sometimes simple 
> domains turn out to be so difficult=
. If I don't come up with anything in 
> a few days, I'll write it up anywa=
y.
> 
> I'd be happy to hear suggestions from the group on better ways to 
=
> coevolve a better player. I've been toying around with dual populations 
=
> where one is O and the other is X, similar to the host-parasite setup I 
=
> posted at the end of part 2, but no luck so far. The only other ideas I 
=
> have left are to drastically increase the population size or to add in 
>=
 an optimal opponent with random noise like Fogel did originally. I 
> hesi=
tate to do the latter though, as coevolution is generally a more 
> elegant=
 solution.
